ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how we can think about life in a separate space from living it. I learned a great deal about the world because this course covers a variety of religions including Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism, Islam, and some more interesting ones such as what is termed individual expressionism.
How different traditions think about the question of a life worth living.
General introduction into world schools of thought and religions with attention to what they believe makes life worth living. Strong focus on student insight in seminar discussions.
A great introduction to the world's preeminent traditions, and fleshing out your own positive vision of a good life.

I developed a very strong personal vision of a life was living. It was super helpful not only to learn a lot about myself and my priorities, but also to compare them to those of others, and realize that WOW, people have such different visions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Very interesting to do the readings of each of the modules, all of which I found something personally engaging with. 

Weakness: discussions could go off track, but it is difficult to know what is "on track" in such a broad course as this.

Ryan is a great instructor and facilitator! Strength is that you get to learn about many different traditions and have a group of ppl willing to discuss and share their thoughts. Weaknesses: there isnt a great flow in how the syllabus moves from one unit to the next.

Strengths: Classes prioritize student insight into what makes their life worth living. Professors help facilitate an environment that is both encouraging and critical in articulating visions of the good life. Readings are manageable and interesting!

Weaknesses: Weekly lectures felt a bit hit or miss at times.

The strengths and weaknesses of this course will really be up to your section classmates and leader. I was really fortunate to have a fantastic group of students and Ryan was awesome. The discussions could sometimes become somewhat high-level, but usually, I got a lot out of seminar time.

strengths: incredibly interesting readings and discussions. Prof Ryan was also amazing. And the retreat too. 
weaknesses: grading was actually kind of harsh. It felt very constraining to be writing essays about how you think life should be lived and being criticized for not following a specific format / including certain points.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES!! Please take it w/ Ryan who is the absolute best! Grading is a bit hard, but you'll learn SO MUCH. The retreat and just engaging in these life questions w/ your peers is so amazing.
Yes, I would say the readings in this course are vital. They will help you appreciate different perspectives that you may have never come into contact with.

YES! Please take it. Great class for senior spring. Take it with Ryan. Take a look at the book Life Worth Living: A Guide to What Matters Most, it basically has a short summary about the class material (but of course taking the class is a much richer experience). Also the retreat is a highlight! This class really builds a community.

I would recommend this course to a student interested in an introduction to world schools of thought / religions with a strong priority to learn from student insight. The quality of the class is highly dependent on how your classmates engage with each other.
Definitely  it was the perfect class for a second-semester senior.

ABSOLUTELY YES. Doesn't matter what age / major / belief system you are, this course will help you think through what you believe is important and literally just how you want to lead your life. You will examine so many different belief systems and parts of yourself. The workload is quite light, but I did all of the readings because they were so interesting. TAKE THIS COURSE.
